title: Andrew Luck retiring has sent the Colts down a QB hellhole
text:
Ever since that day, no other Colts QB has come even close to the high level of quarterback play he gave all Colts fans during his time in Indy. Quarterback Rating (QBR) looks at the total contribution that the player made to the team on a particular play and over the entire season.
Let’s look at Colts quarterback QBR since 2012 when Andrew Luck was a rookie.


Code
library(tidyverse)

qbstats <- read_csv("qbs.csv")
coltsqbstats <- qbstats %>%
  filter(Tm == "IND" & G>7) %>%
  select(Player, QBR, Season, G) %>%
  mutate(PlayerSeason = paste(Player,Season))
chosenone <- coltsqbstats%>%
  filter(Player== "Andrew Luck")

ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data= coltsqbstats,
    aes(x= reorder(PlayerSeason, QBR),
    weight= QBR
  ))+
  geom_bar(
    data = chosenone, 
    aes(x= reorder(PlayerSeason, QBR),
    weight= QBR),
    fill="blue"
    ) + 
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x= "Quarterback",
    y= "QBR",
    title = "Colts Quarterbacks QBR since 2012",
    subtitle = "After Luck retired no QB has been rated higher than him",
    caption = "Source: ProFootball Reference | By: Jake Bunz")+
  theme_minimal()+
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"))





Numbers don’t lie. He is by far the best QB they have had since Peyton Manning. He is the only reason the Colts had any success during his time in Indy.
The biggest surprise to Luck’s retirement was that it came after his best season on the Colts. He had statistically one of the best seasons in the last nine years.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)

qbstats <- read_csv("qbs.csv")
lucky <- qbstats %>% filter(Player == "Andrew Luck" & Season == '2018')
manning <- qbstats %>%
  filter(Yds>5400)
topqb <- qbstats %>%
  filter(Yds > 4500 & TD > 38)

ggplot()+
  geom_point(data = qbstats, aes(x= Yds, y = TD), color= "grey")+
  geom_point(data = topqb, aes(x= Yds, y = TD), color = "black")+
  geom_point(data = lucky, aes(x= Yds, y = TD), color= "blue")+
  geom_point(data = manning, aes(x= Yds, y = TD), color = "orange")+
  geom_encircle(data=topqb, aes(x=Yds, y=TD), s_shape=.5, expand=.03, colour="red")+
  geom_text(aes(x=4000, y= 45, label="Seasons with at least 4500\n Yds and 38 TD"), color="dark grey", size=4)+
  geom_text(aes(x=4800, y=55, label="Peyton Manning"), fontface= "bold")+
  geom_text(aes(x=4100, y=39, label="Andrew Luck"), fontface= "bold")+
  labs(
    x="Passing Yards", 
    y="Touchdowns", 
    title="Quarterback stats from the last 9 seasons", 
    subtitle="Andrew Lucks 2018 season puts him among an elite group of quarterbacks",
    caption="Source: ProFootball Reference | By Jake Bunz") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold")
    ) 





In the years after Luck retired, the Colts offense ran the ball more because they cannot trust the quarterback to throw all over the field. The Colts did not have 2000 rushing yards in any season with Luck at quarterback, but the first year after he retired, they had over 2000. They also had 78 rushing TDs in the Luck era and have 66 already in the three seasons after.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(waffle)

rushing <- c("Luck Era"= 1912, "Everyone Else"=2246)
rushingtd <- c("Luck Era"= 13, "Everyone Else"= 19)

iron(
  waffle(rushing/50,
         rows = 10,
         xlab = "1 square = 50 yards",
         colors = c("black", "blue")) +
    labs(
      title= "The Colts Offensive Shift Post Andrew Luck",
      subtitle = "The Colts averaged more rushing yards and rushing touchdowns in the\n years since the chosen one retired.") +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  ),
   waffle(rushingtd,
         rows = 5,
         xlab = "1 square = 1 TD",
         colors = c("black", "blue")) +
    labs(caption = "Source: ProFootballReference | By: Jake Bunz")
)





Andrew Luck’s retirement is a day I will never forget because he was a fantastic QB who was the bright light on a bad team. He will go down as a Colt legend and one of the best players in the NFL. I only wish the Colts front office would quit making me watch the QB clown show every year.

title: Mike Trout and Shohei Ohtani are the Angels
text:
Mike Trout and Shohei Ohtani are some of the best players in baseball and definitley the best on the Angels. What you might not know is that the rest of the Angels haven’t done much in supporting their standout stars.
The numbers are shocking.
Wins above replacement (WAR), is the stat that was developed to basically show the players contribution to their team. So we will look at WAR for every player in the MLB for this last season.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(scales)
war <- read_csv("fangraphs-war-leaderboard.csv")
topwar<- war %>%
  filter(`Total WAR`>3.84)%>%
  arrange(desc(`Total WAR`))%>%
  select(Name, `Total WAR`, Team)

angelswar <- topwar %>%
  filter(Team == "LAA")


ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data = topwar,
    aes(x= reorder(Name, `Total WAR`), weight= `Total WAR`), fill= "grey") +
  geom_bar(
    data = angelswar,
    aes(x= reorder(Name, `Total WAR`), weight= `Total WAR`), fill= "red")+
  labs(
    title="How good are they actually?",
    subtitle = "Shohei Ohtani and Mike Trout are in the top 20 of WAR, but there isn't another Angel until 76.",
    x= "Player Name",
    y= "Total WAR",
caption= "By: Jake Bunz | Source: FanGraphs")+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size= 20, face="bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 8),
        plot.title.position = "plot")+
  coord_flip()





Shohei finished 2nd in the MLB for WAR this year with Trout closely behind him. Trout missed 40 games this year due to injuries and he still finished in the top 20.
This demonstrates how good they are compared to the rest of the league, but how do they stack up with the rest of the Angels?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(cowplot)
library(gt)
library(scales)
hittingstats <- read_csv("angelsteamhitting.csv") %>% mutate(Name = gsub("\\*", "", Name)) %>% mutate(Name = gsub("\\#", "", Name))
hittingdata <- hittingstats %>%
  filter(G>1)%>%
  mutate(ExtraBaseHits= (`2B`+`3B`), Singles = H-ExtraBaseHits) %>% select(Name, Singles, ExtraBaseHits, HR, RBI) %>% pivot_longer(cols=(-Name), names_to="Type", values_to = "Number")



bar1 <- ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data= hittingdata,
    aes(x=reorder(Name, Number), weight= Number, fill= Type)
  )+
  labs(title = "Carrying the offense",subtitle = "Trout and Ohtani lead the team in producing the most offense in 2022",
       x= "Player Name",
       y= "Ammount")+
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )

percentage <- read_csv("percentage.csv")

bar2 <- ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data= percentage,
    aes(x= Type, weight=Percent, fill=Name))+
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("black","red"))+
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(title = "Percentage of offense",
       x="",
       y= "Percent",
caption= "By: Jake Bunz | Source: Baseball Reference")+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )

plot_grid(bar1, bar2, ncol = 1)





They produce nearly 30% of all major offensive categories on their team. Having nearly a third of all team offense rely on two players isn’t exactly a recipe for success.
That’s just offense, let’s look at pitching stats from the Angels starting rotation.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(scales)
pitchingstats <- read_csv("anglesteampitching.csv") %>% mutate(Name = gsub("\\*", "", Name)) %>% mutate(Name = gsub("\\#", "", Name))

starters <- pitchingstats %>%
  filter(GS>8) %>%
  select(Name, W, L, ERA, IP, SO, WHIP, `SO9`)

starters %>% gt() %>%
  tab_header(title = "Ohtani is the single star in the starting rotation.",
             subtitle = "He leads the team in all major pitching categories.")%>%
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) %>% tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )%>%
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Jake Bunz | **Source:** Baseball Reference")
  )%>%
  tab_style(
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
    style = list(
      cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
      cell_text(weight = "bold", size = 15)
    )
  )%>%
  opt_row_striping()%>%
  opt_table_lines("none")%>%
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color="red"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Name == "Shohei Ohtani")
  )

Shohei is the work horse for the Angels rotation and his numbers put him in elite company at the top of the league. The rest of the starters were no where close to Shohei.
If the Angels want to win in the future they can’t just hope Trout and Ohtani pull the team along. They need to find pieces that will support their stars and team as a whole.
